docs.lead_paragraph: A government data warehouse that stores personal information on millions of HealthCare.gov customers is raising privacy concerns at a time when major breaches have become distressingly common.

headline.main: Vast Data Warehouse Raises HealthCare.gov Privacy Concerns
headline.print_headline: Vast Data Warehouse Raises HealthCare.gov Privacy Concerns

docs.snippet: A government data warehouse that stores personal information on millions of HealthCare.gov customers is raising privacy concerns at a time when major breaches have become distressingly common.

docs.lead_paragraph: No one wants to make a repeat visit to the emergency room for the same complaint, but new research suggests it's more common than previously thought and surprisingly, people frequently wind up at a different ER the second time around.

headline.main: Study on ER Returns Suggests More Need for Follow-Up Care
headline.print_headline: Study on ER Returns Suggests More Need for Follow-Up Care

docs.snippet: No one wants to make a repeat visit to the emergency room for the same complaint, but new research suggests it's more common than previously thought and surprisingly, people frequently wind up at a different ER the second time around.

docs.lead_paragraph: Financial-services jobs are leaving New York, lured by lower costs.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by policy expert Kathryn S Wylde warns New York City has seen net loss of 25,000 financial services jobs over past five years as banks downsize and seek to cut costs; argues critics of Wall Street should remember majority of financial service workers in city are middle class, and industry accounts for some 62 percent of private-sector wages in city; calls on government to secure industry through several initiatives.
docs.snippet: Financial-services jobs are leaving New York, lured by lower costs.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Supreme Court endorsement of gay marriage would still leave many parents fighting to share custody of their same-sex partner’s children.

headline.main: Same-Sex Parents’ Rights May Be Unresolved After Justices’ Ruling
headline.print_headline: Same-Sex Parents’ Rights May Be Unresolved

docs.abstract: Supreme Court decision on nationwide legalization of same-sex marriage, if ruling is favorable, will still leave some parental issues unresolved; ruling would extend the right to adopt to gay couples, but nonbiological parents will likely have to go through courts in order to cement legal ties with their partner's children.
docs.snippet: A Supreme Court endorsement of gay marriage would still leave many parents fighting to share custody of their same-sex partner’s children.

keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: In June 2015, the Times profiled David Elson, a chronically ill Kentucky man who signed up for insurance through the Affordable Care Act but lost it after not paying the premiums.

headline.main: A Hard Road to Health Insurance

docs.snippet: In June 2015, the Times profiled David Elson, a chronically ill Kentucky man who signed up for insurance through the Affordable Care Act but lost it after not paying the premiums.
